titleStmt.title: THE MOST EXCELLENT AND Lamentable Tragedie, of Romeo and Juliet. As it hath beene sundrie times publiquely Acted, by the KINGS Majesties Seruants at the Globe. Newly corrected, augmented, and amended:

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for John Smethwick, and to be sold at his Shop in Saint Dunstanes Church-yard, in Fleetestreete under the Dyall.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by iDREF pointing to information in the following declaration.
Romeo; Son to Montague Juliet; Daughter to Capulet Nurse; Nurse to Juliet Benvolio; Nephew to Montague and Friend to Romeo Mercutio; Kinsman to Escalus and Friend to Romeo Friar Laurence; Franciscan friar Capulet; Head of the House of Capulet Lady Capulet; Wife to Capulet Paris; Kinsman to Escalus and a young nobleman Tibalt; Nephew to Lady Capulet
Sampson; Servant to Capulet Prince Escalus; Prince of Verona Gregory; Servant to Capulet Peter; Servant to Juliet's Nurse Balthasar; Servant to Romeo Montague; Head of the House of Montague
Abraham; Servant to Montague Friar Johan; Franciscan friar Lady Montague; Wife to Montague Apothecary Servant First Servant First Musician First Watchman Second Servant Page Officer Second Musician Chorus Second Capulet Second Watchman Third Musician Third Watchman Unknown

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following:

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Two households both alike in dignity,
(In fair Verona where we lay our Scene)
From ancient grudge, break to new mutiny,
Where civil blood makes civil hands unclean:
From forth the fatal loins of these two foes,
A pair of star-crossed lovers, take their life:
Whose misadventured piteous overthrows,
Doth with their death bury their Parents strife.
The fearful passage of their death-marked love,
And the continuance of their Parents rage,
Which but their children's end nought could remove:
Is now the two hours traffic of our Stage.
The which if you with patient ears attend,
What here shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend:

div1.head: THE MOST EXCELLENT AND Lamentable Tragedy of ROMEO and IVLIET.

div2.stage: Enter Sampson and Gregorie, with Swords and Bucklers, of the house of Capulet.

sp.speaker: SAmp.
sp.p: Gregorie, on my word we will not carry Coals.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: No, for then we should be Colliers.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: I mean, and we be in choler, we will draw.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I while you live, draw your neck out of choler:

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: I strike quickly being moved.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: A dog of the house of Mountague moves me.

sp.speaker: Grego.
sp.p:
To move is to stir, and to be valiant, is to stand.
Therefore if thou art moved thou runnest away.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p:
A dog of that house shall move me to stand.
I will take the wall of any man or maid of Mountagues.

sp.speaker: Grego.
sp.p: That shows thee a weak slave, for the weakest goes to the wall.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p:
It is true, and therefore women being the weaker
vessels are ever thrust to the wall: therefore I will push Mountagues
men from the wall, and thrust his maids to the wall.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: The quarrel is between our masters, and us their men.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p:
It is all one, I will show myself a tyrant, when I have
fought with the men, I will be civil with the maids, I will cut
off their heads.

sp.speaker: Grego.
sp.p: The heads of the maids.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p:
Aye the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads, take
it in what sense thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Grego.
sp.p: They must take it sense that feele it.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p:
Me they shall feele while I am able to stand, and it is
known I am a pretty piece of flesh.

sp.speaker: Grego.
sp.p:
It is well thou art not fish, if thou hadst, thou hadst
been poor Iohn: draw thy tool here comes of the house of
Mountagues.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: My naked weapon is out, quarrel, I will back thee.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: How, turn thy back and run?

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Fear me not.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: No marry, I fear thee.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Let us take the law of our sides, let them begin.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as they list.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p:
Nay as they dare, I will bite my thumb at them, which
is disgrace to them if they bear it.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Do you bite your thumb at us sir?

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: I do bite my thumb sir.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Do you bite your thumb at us sir?

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Is the law of our side if I say Aye?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p:
No sir, I do not bite my thumb at you sir, but I bite
my thumb sir.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Do you quarrel sir?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Quarrel sir, no sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: But if you do sir, I am for you, I serve as good a man as you.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: No better.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Say better, here comes one of my Master's kinsmen.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Yes better sir.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: You lie.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p:
Draw if you be men, Gregorie, remember thy washing
blow.

sp.speaker: Benu.
sp.p:
Part fools, put up your swords, you know not what
you do.

sp.speaker: Tibalt.
sp.l: What art thou drawn among these heartless hinds
turn thee Benuolio, look upon thy death.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I do but keep the peace, put up thy sword,
or manage it to part these men with me.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: What drawn and talk of peace? I hate the word,
as I hate hell, all Mountagues and thee:
Have at thee coward.

div2.stage: Enter three or foure Citizens with Clubs or partysons.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Clubs, Bills and Partisans, strike, beat them down,
Down with the Capulets, down with the Mountagues.

div2.stage: Enter old Capulet in his gowne, and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: What noise is this? give me my long sword ho,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: A crutch, a crutch, why call you for a sword?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: My sword I say, old Mountague is come,
And flourishes his blade in spite of me.

div2.stage: Enter old Mountague and his wife.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Thou villain Capulet, hold me not, let me go.

sp.speaker: M. Wife. 2.
sp.l: Thou shalt not stir one foot to seek a foe.

div2.stage: Enter Prince Eskales, with his traine.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Rebellious subjects enemies to peace,
Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel,
Will they not hear? what ho, you men, you beasts:
That quench the fire of your pernicious rage,
With purple fountains issuing from your veins:
On pain of torture from those bloody hands,
Throw your mistempered weapons to the ground,
And hear the sentence of your moved Prince.
Three civil brawls bred of an airy word,
By thee old Capulet and Mountague,
Have thrice disturbed the quiet of our streets,
And made Ueronas ancient Citizens,
Cast by their grave beseeming ornaments,
To wield old partisans, in hands as old,
Cankered with peace, to part your cankered hate,
If ever you disturb our streets again,
Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.
For this time all the rest depart away:
You Capulet shall go along with me,
And Mountague come you this afternoon,
To know our Fathers pleasure in this case:
To old Free-town, our common judgment place:
Once more on pain of death, all men depart.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?
Speak Nephew, were you by, when it began?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Here were the servants of your adversary
And yours, close fighting ere I did approach,
I drew to part them, in the instant came
The fiery Tibalt, with his sword prepared,
Which as he breathed defiance to my ears,
He swung about his head and cut the winds,
Who nothing hurt withal, hist him in scorn:
While we were interchanging thrusts and blows,
Came more and more, and fought on part and part,
Till the Prince came, who parted either part.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O where is Romeo, saw you him today?
Right glad I am, he was not at this fray.

sp.speaker: Benuo.
sp.l: Madam, an hour before the worshipped Sun,
Peered forth the golden window of the East,
A troubled mind drove me to walk abroad,
Where underneath the grove of Syramour,
That Westward rooteth from this City side:
So early walking did I see your son,
Towards him I made, but he was ware of me,
And stole into the covert of the wood,
I measuring his affections by my own,
Which then most sought, where most might not be found:
Being one too many by my weary self,
Pursued my honour, not pursuing his,
And gladly shunned, who gladly fled from me.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Many a morning hath he there been seen,
With tears augmenting the fresh mornings dew,
Adding to clouds, more clouds with his deep sighs,
But all so soon, as the all cheering Sun,
Should in the farthest East begin to draw,
The shady curtains from Aurora's bed,
Away from light steals home my heavy son,
And private in his Chamber pens himself,
Shuts up his windows, locks fair daylight out,
And makes himself an artificial night,
Black and portentous must this humour prove,
Unless good counsel may the cause remove.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My Noble uncle do you know the cause?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: I neither know it, nor can learn of him.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Have you importuned him by any means?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Both by myself and many other friends,
But he his own affections counsellor,
Is to himself (I will not say how true)
But to himself so secret and so close,
So far from sounding and discovery,
As is the bud bit with an envious worm,
Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air,
Or dedicate his beauty to the same.
Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow,
We would as willingly give cure as know.

sp.speaker: Benu.
sp.l: See where he comes, so please you step aside,
I will know his grievance or be much denied.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: I would thou wert so happy by thy stay,
To hear true shrift, come Madam let us away.

sp.speaker: Benuol.
sp.l: Good morrow Cousin.

sp.speaker: Romeo.
sp.l: Is the day so young?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: But new struck nine.

sp.speaker: Romeo.
sp.l: Aye me sad hours seem long:
Was that my father that went hence so fast?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: It was: what sadness lengthens Romeos hours?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Not having that, which having, makes the short.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: In love.

sp.speaker: Romeo.
sp.l: Out.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Of love.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Out of her favour where I am in love.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Alas that love so gentle in his view,
Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof.

sp.speaker: Romeo.
sp.l: Alas that love, whose view is muffled still,
Should without eyes, see pathways to his will:
Where shall we dine? O me: what fray was here?
Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all:
Here is much to do with hate, but more with love:
Why then O brawling love, O loving hate,
O anything of nothing first created:
O heavy lightness, serious vanity,
Misshapen Chaos of well-seeing forms,
Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health,
Still waking sleep that is not what it is.
This love feele I, that feele no love in this,
Doest thou not laugh?

sp.speaker: Benu.
sp.l: No Cuz, I rather weep.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Good heart at what?

sp.speaker: Benu.
sp.l: At thy good hearts oppression.

sp.speaker: Romeo.
sp.l: Why such is love's transgression:
Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast,
Which thou wilt propagate to have it pressed,
With more of thine, this love that thou hast shown,
Doth add more grief, to too much of mine own.
Love is a smoke made with the fume of sighs,
Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes,
Being vexed, a sea nourished with loving tears,
What is it else? a madness, most discreet,
A choking gall, and a preserving sweet:
Farewell my Cuz.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Soft I will go along.
And if you leave me so, you do me wrong.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Tut I have lost myself, I am not here,
This is not Romeo, he is some other where.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tell me in sadness, who is that you love?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What shall I groan and tell thee?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Groan, why no: but sadly tell me who?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: A sick man in sadness makes his will:
A word ill urged to one that is so ill:
In sadness Cousin, I do love a woman.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I aimed so near, when I supposed you loved.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: A right good mark man, and she is fair I love.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: A right fair mark fair Cuz is soonest hit.

sp.speaker: Romeo.
sp.l: Well in that hit you miss, she will not be hit
With Cupids arrow, she hath Dianne's wit:
And in strong proof of chastity well armed,
From love's weak childish bow she lives uncharmed.
She will not stay the siege of loving terms,
Nor bide the encounter of assailing eyes.
Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold,
O she is rich in beauty only poor,
That when she dies, with beauty dies her store.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Then she hath sworn, that she will still live chaste?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: She hath, and in that sparing, make huge waste:
For beauty starved with her severity,
Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair,
To merit bliss by making me despair:
She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow,
Do I live dead, that live to tell it now.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Be ruled by me, forget to think of her.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O teach me how I should forget to think.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: By giving liberty unto thine eyes,
Examine other beauties.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: It is the way to call hers (exquisite) in question more,
These happy masks that kiss fair Ladies brows,
Being black, puts us in mind they hide the fair:
He that is strucken blind, cannot forget
The precious treasure of his eye-sight lost,
Show me a Mistress that is passing fair,
What doth her beauty serve but as a note,
Where I may read who past that passing fair:
Farewell thou canst not teach me to forget,

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I will pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.

div2.stage: Enter Capulet, Countie Paris, and the Clowne.

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: But Mountague is bound as well as I,
In penalty alike, and it is not hard I think,
For men so old as we to keep the peace.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Of honourable reckoning are you both,
And pity it is, you lived at odds so long:
But now my Lord, what say you to my suit?

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: But saying over what I have said before,
My child is yet a stranger in the world,
She hath not seen the change of fourteen years,
Let two more Summers wither in their pride,
Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.

sp.speaker: Pari.
sp.l: Younger than she, are happy mothers made.

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: And too soon marred are those so early made:
Earth hath swallowed all my hopes but she,
She is the hopeful Lady of my earth:
But woo her gentle Paris, get her heart,
My will to her consent, is but a part.
And she agreed, within her scope of choice
Lies my consent, and fair according voice:
This night I hold, an old accustomed feast,
Whereto I have invited many a guest:
Such as I love, and you among the store,
One more, most welcome makes my number more:
At my poor house, look to behold this night,
Earthtreading stars, that make dark heaven light:
Such comfort as do lusty young men feele,
When well appareled April on the heel,
Of limping winter treads, even such delight
Among fresh fennel buds shall you this night
Inherit at my house, hear all, all see:
And like her most, whose merit most shall be:
Which one more view, of many, mine being one,
May stand in number, though in reckoning none.
Come go with me, go sirrah trudge about,
Through fair Verona, find those persons out,
Whose names are written there, and to them say,
My house and welcome,on their pleasure stay.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p:
Find them out whose names are written. Here it is written,
that the shoemaker should meddle with his yard, and the
tailor with his last, the fisher with his pencil, and the painter with
his nets. But I am sent to find those persons whose names are
here writ, and can never find what names the writing person
hath here writ (I must to the learned) in good time.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tut man, one fire burns out, an others burning,
One pain is lessened by an others anguish,
Turn giddy, and be helped by backward turning:
One desperate grief, cures with an others languish:
Take thou some new infection to thy eye,
And the rank poison of the old will die.

sp.speaker: Romeo.
sp.l: Your Plantain leaf is excellent for that.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: For what I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Romeo.
sp.l: For your broken shin.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Why Romeo, art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Not mad, but bound more than a mad man is:
Shut up in prison, kept without my food,
Whipped and tormented, and Godden good fellow.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Godgigoden, I pray sir can you read?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Aye mine own fortune in my misery.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Perhaps you have learned it without book:
But I pray can you read anything you see?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Aye if I know the letters and the language.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Ye say honestly, rest you merry.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Stay fellow, I can read.
SEigneur Martino, and his wife and daughters: County Anselme
and his beauteous sisters: the Lady widow of Vtruuio, Seigneur
Placentio, and his lovely Nieces: Mercutio and his brother Valentine:
mine Uncle Capulet his wife and daughters: my fair Niece
Rosaline, Liuia, Seigneur Valentio, and his Cousin Tybalt: Lucio
and the lively Hellena.
A fair assembly, whither should they come?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Up.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Whither to supper?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: To our house.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Whose house?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My Masters.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Indeed I should have asked you that before.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Now I will tell you without asking. My master is the great
rich Capulet, and if you be not of the house of Mountagues, I
pray come and crush a cup of wine. Rest you merry.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: At this same ancient feast of Capulets,
Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so loves:
With all the admired beauties of Verona,
Go thither, and with untainted eye,
Compare her face with some that I shall show,
And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: When the devout religion of mine eye.
Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fire:
And these who often drowned, could never die,
Transparent Heretics be burnt for liars.
One fairer than my love, the all seeing Sun,
Never saw her match, since first the world begun.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tut you saw her fair none else being by,
Herself poised with herself in either eye:
But in that Crystal scales let there be weighed,
Your Ladies love against some other maid:
That I will show you shining at this feast,
And she shall scant show well that now seems best.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I will go along no such sight to be shown,
But to rejoice in splendour of mine own.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Nurse where is my daughter? call her forth to me.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Now by my maidenhead, at twelve year old I bad her
come, what Lamb, what Lady-bird, God forbid,
Where is this Girl? what Iuliet.

sp.speaker: Iuliet.
sp.l: How now who calls?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Your mother.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Madam I am here, what is your will?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: This is the matter. Nurse give leave a while, we must talk
in secret. Nurse come back again, I have remembered me,
thou shall hear our counsel. Thou knowest my daughters of a pretty age.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Faith I can tell her age unto an hour.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: She is not fourteen.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p:
I will lay fourteen of my teeth, and yet to my teen be it
spoken, I have but four, she is not fourteen.
How long is it now to Lammas tide?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: A fortnight and odd days.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Even or odd, of all days in the year come Lammas Eve at
night shall she be fourteen. Susan and she, God rest all Christian souls,
were of an age. Well Susan is with God, she was too good for me: But
as I said, on Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen, that shall
she marry, I remember it well. It is since the Earth-quake now
eleven years, and she was weaned I never shall forget it, of all the days
of the year upon that day: for I had then laid wormwood to my
dug, sitting in the sun under the Dove-house wall. My Lord and
you were then at Mantua, nay I do bear a brain. But as I said,
when it did taste the wormwood on the nipple of my dug, and
felt it bitter, pretty fool, to see it tetchy and fall out with the Dug.
Shake quoth the Dove-house, it was no need I trow to bid me trudge:
and since that time it is eleven years, for then she could stand alone,
nay by the rood she could have run and waddled all about: for even
the day before she broke her brow, and then my husband, God be with
his soul, he was a merry man, took up the child, yea quoth he, doest
thou fall upon thy face? thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more
wit, wilt thou not Iule? And by my holydam, the pretty wretch left
crying, and said I: to see now how a jest shall come about: I warrant,
if I should live a thousand years, I never should forget it: wilt thou
not Iule quoth he? and pretty fool it stinted, and said Aye.

sp.speaker: Old La.
sp.l: Enough of this, I pray thee hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Yes Madam, yet I can not choose but laugh, to think it
should leave crying, and say Aye: and yet I warrant it had upon it brow, a
bump as big as a young Cockerels stone: a perilous knock, and it cried
bitterly. Yea quoth my husband, fallest upon thy face, thou wilt fall
backward when thou comest to age: wilt thou not Iule? It stinted,
and said Aye.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: And stint thou too, I pray thee Nurse, say Aye.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Peace I have done: God mark thee too his grace, thou
wast the prettiest babe that ere I nursed, if I might live to see thee
married once, I have my wish.

sp.speaker: Old La.
sp.l: Marry, that marry is the very theme
I came to talk of, tell me daughter Iuliet,
How stands your dispositions to be married?

sp.speaker: Iuliet.
sp.l: It is an hour that I dream not of.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: An hour, were not I thine only Nurse, I would say thou
hadst sucked wisdom from thy teat.

sp.speaker: Old La.
sp.l: Well think of marriage now, younger than you
Here in Verona, Ladies of esteem,
Are made already mothers by my count.
I was your mother, much upon these years
That you are now a maid, thus then in brief:
The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: A man young Lady, Lady, such a man as all the world.
Why he is a man of wax.

sp.speaker: OldLa.
sp.l: Verona's Summer hath not such a flower.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Nay he is a flower, in faith a very flower.

sp.speaker: Old La.
sp.l: What say you, can you love the Gentleman?
This night you shall behold him at our feast,
Read over the volume of young Paris face,
And find delight, writ there with beauty's pen,
Examine every married lineament,
And see how one an other lends content:
And what obscured in this fair volume lies,
Find written in the margin of his eyes.
This precious book of love, this unbound lover,
To beautify him, only lacks a Cover.
The fish lives in the sea, and it is much pride
For fair without the fair, within to hide:
That book in many's eyes doth share the glory
That in gold clasps locks in the golden story:
So shall you share all that he doth possess,
By having him, making yourself no less.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: No less, nay bigger women grow by men.

sp.speaker: OldLa.
sp.l: Speak briefly, can you like of Paris love?

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: I will look to like, if looking liking move.
But no more deep will I endart mine eye,
Than your consent gives strength to make fly.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Madam the guests are come, supper served up, you called,
my young Lady asked for, the Nurse cursed in the Pantry, and everything in extremity: I must hence to wait, I beseech you
follow straight.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: We follow thee, Iuliet the County stays.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Go girl, seek happy nights to happy days.

div2.stage: Enter Romeo, Mercutio, Benuolio, with fiue or sixe other Maskers, torchbearers.

sp.speaker: Romeo.
sp.l: What shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?
Or shall we on without apology?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The date is out of such prolixity,
We will have no Cupid, hoodwinked with a scarf,
Bearing a Tartars painted bow of lath,
Scaring the Ladies like a Crowkeeper.
But let them measure us by what they will,
We will measure them a measure and be gone.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Give me a torch, I am not for this ambling,
Being but heavy I will bear the light.

sp.speaker: Mercu.
sp.l: Nay gentle Romeo,we must have you dance.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Not I believe me, you have dancing shoes
With nimble soles, I have a soul of Lead
So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are a Lover, borrow Cupids wings,
And soar with them above a common bound.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I am too sore enpierced with his shaft,
To soar with his light feathers, and so bound,
I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe,
Under love's heavy burthen do I sink.

sp.speaker: Horatio.
sp.l: And to sink in it should you burthen love,
Too great oppression for a tender thing.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Is love a tender thing? it is too rough,
Too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorne.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: If love be rough with you, be rough with love
Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down,
Give me a case to put my visage in,
A vizor for a vizor, what care I
What curious eye doth cote deformities:
Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me.

sp.speaker: Benu.
sp.l: Come knock and enter, and no sooner in,
But every man betake him to his legs.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: A torch for me, let wantons light of heart
Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels:
For I am proverbed with a grungier phrase,
I will be a candle-holder and look on,
The game was never so fair, and I am dumb.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Tut, duns the mouse, the Constables own word:
If thou art dun, we will draw thee from the mire
Or save you reverence love, wherein thou stickest
Up to the ears, come we burn daylight ho.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Nay that is not so.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I mean sir in delay
We waste our lights in vain, lights lights by day:
Take our good meaning, for our judgement sits,
Five times in that, ere once in our fine wits.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: And we mean well in going to this Mask,
But it is no wit to go.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why, may one ask?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I dreamt a dream tonight.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And so did I.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Well what was yours?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That dreamers often lie.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: In bed asleep while they do dream things true.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O then I see Queen Mab hath been with you:
She is the Fairies midwife, and she comes in shape no bigger than
an Agate stone, on the forefinger of an Alderman, drawn with
a team of little atomies, over men's noses as they lie asleep: her
waggonspokes made of log spinners legs: the cover, of the wings
of Grasshoppers, her traces of the smallest spider web, her colours
of the moonshines watery beams, her whip of Crickets bone, the
lash of Philome, her waggoner, a small grey coated Gnat, not
half so big as a round little worm, pricked from the lazy finger of
a man. Her Chariot is an empty Hazel nut, Made by the Joiner
squirrel or old Grub, time out of mind, the Fairy Coach-makers:
and in this state she gallops night by night, through lovers' brains,
and then they dream of love. On Courtiers knees, that dream
on Curtsies strait over Lawyers fingers who strait dream on fees,
over Ladies lips who strait on kisses dream, which oft the angry
Mab with blisters plagues, because their breath with sweet
meats tainted are. Sometime she gallops over a Courtiers nose,
and then dreams he of smelling out a suit: and sometime comes
she with a tithe-pig's tale, tickling a Parsons nose as he lies asleep,
then he dreams of another Benefice. Sometime she driveth over
a soldier's neck, and then dreams he of cutting foreign throats,
of breaches, ambuscados, spanish blades: Of healths five fathom
deep, and then anon drums in his ear, at which he starts and
wakes, and being thus frighted, swears a prayer or two, and sleeps
again: this is that very Mab that plaits the manes of horses in the
night: and bakes the Elklocks in foul sluttish hairs, which
once untangled, much misfortune bodes.
This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs,
That presses them and learns them first to bear,
Making them women of good carriage:
This is she.

sp.speaker: Romeo.
sp.l: Peace, peace, Mercutio peace,
Thou talkest of nothing.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: True, I talk of dreams:
Which are the children of an idle brain,
Begot of nothing but vain fantasy:
Which is as thin of substance as the air,
And more inconstant than the wind who woos,
Even now the frozen bosom of the North:
And being angered puffs away from thence,
Turning his side to the dew dropping South.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This wind you talk of, blows us from ourselves,
Supper is done, and we shall come too late.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I fear too early, for my mind misgives,
Some consequence yet hanging in the stars,
Shall bitterly begin his fearful date,
With this nights revels, and expire the term
Of a despised life closed in my breast:
By some vile forfeit of untimely death.
But he that hath the steerage of my course,
Direct my suit, on lusty Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Strike drum.

div2.stage: They march about the Stage, and Seruing men come forth with Napkins.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Where is Potpan that he helps not to take away?
He shift a trencher, he scrape a trencher?

When good manners shall lie all in one or two men's hands
And they unwashed too, it is a foul thing.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Away with the joint-stools, remove the court-cupboard,
look to the plate, good thou, save me a piece of March-pane,
and as thou loves me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone, and
Nell, Anthonie and Potpan.
Aye boy ready.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
You are looked for, and called for, asked for, and sought for in
the great chamber.

We cannot be here and there too, cheerly boys,
Be brisk a while, and the longer liver take all.

div2.stage: Enter all the guests and gentlewomen to the Maskers.

sp.speaker: 1. Capu.
sp.l: Welcome gentlemen, Ladies that have their toes
Unpleased with Corns, will walk about with you:
Ah my mistresses, which of you all
Will now deny to dance, she that makes dainty,
She I will swear hath Corns: am I come near ye now?
Welcome gentlemen, I have seen the day
That I have worn a vizor and could tell
A whispering tale in a fair Ladies ear:
Such as would please: it is gone, it is gone, it is gone,
You are welcome, gentlemen come, Musicians play.
A hall, a hall, give room, and foot it girls,
More light you knaves, and turn the tables up:
And quench the fire, the room is grown too hot.
Ah sirrah, this unlooked for sport comes well:
Nay sit, nay sit, good Cousin Capulet,
For you and I are past our dancing days:
How long is it now since last yourself and I
Were in a mask?

sp.speaker: 2. Capu.
sp.l: Byrlady thirty years.

sp.speaker: 1. Capu.
sp.l: What man it is not so much, it is not so much,
It is since the nuptial of Lucientio:
Come Pentecost as quickly as it will,
Some five and twenty years, and then we masked.

sp.speaker: 2. Capu.
sp.l: It is more, it is more, his son is elder sir:
His son is thirty.

sp.speaker: 1. Capu.
sp.l: Will you tell me that?
His son was but a ward two years ago.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What Lady is that which doth enrich the hand
Of yonder Knight?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I know not sir.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: O she doth teach the torches to burn bright:
It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night:
As a rich Jewel in an Ethiop's ear,
Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear:
So shows a snowy Dove trooping with Crows,
As yonder Lady over her fellows shows:
The measure done, I will watch her place of stand,
And touching hers, make blessed my rude hand.
Did my heart love till now, forswear it sight,
For I never saw true beauty till this night.

sp.speaker: Tibal.
sp.l: This by his voice, should be a Mountague.
Fetch me my Rapier boy, what dares the slave
Come hither covered with an antique face,
To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?
Now by the stock and honour of my kin,
To strike him dead, I hold it not a sin.

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: Why how now kinsman, wherefore storm you so?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Uncle, this is a Mountague our foe:
A villain that is hither come in spite,
To scorn at our solemnity this night.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Young Romeo is it.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: It is he, that villain Romeo.

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: Content thee gentle Cuz, let him alone,
He bears him like a portly Gentleman:
And to say truth, Verona brags of him,
To be a virtuous and well-governed youth,
I would not for the wealth of all this Town,
Here in my house do him disparagement:
Therefore be patient, take no note of him,
It is my will, the which if thou respect,
Show a fair presence, and put off these frowns,
An illbeseeming semblance for a feast.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: It fits when such a villain is a guest,
I will not endure him.

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: He shall be endured.
What goodman boy, I say he shall, go to,
Am I the master here or you? go to,
You will not endure him, god shall mend my soul,
You will make a mutiny among my guests:
You will set cock a hoop, you will be the man.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Why Uncle, it is a shame.

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: Go to, go to,
You are a saucy boy, is it so indeed?
This trick may chance to scathe you I know what,
You must contrary me, marry it is time,
Well said my hearts, you are a princox, go,
Be quiet, or more light, more light for shame,
I will make you quiet (what) cheerly my hearts.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Patience perforce, with wilful choler meeting,
Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting:
I will withdraw, but this intrusion shall
Now seeming sweet, convert to bitterest gall.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: If I profane with my unworthiest hand,
This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this,
My lips two blushing Pilgrims did ready stand,
To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Good Pilgrim you do wrong your hand too much
Which mannerly devotion shows in this,
For saints have hands, that Pilgrims hands do touch,
And palm to palm is holy Palmers kiss.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Have not Saints lips and holy Palmers too?

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Aye Pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O then dear Saint, let lips do what hands do,
They pray (grant thou) lest faith turn to despair.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Saints do not move, though grant for prayers sake.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Then move not while my prayers effect I take,
Thus from my lips, by thine my sin is purged.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Then have my lips the sin that they have took.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Sin from my lips, o trespass sweetly urged:
Give me my sin again.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: You kiss by the book.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Madam your mother craves a word with you.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What is her mother?

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.l: Marry Bachelor,
Her mother is the Lady of the house,
And a good Lady, and a wise and virtuous,
I Nursed her daughter that you talked withal:
I tell you, he that can lay hold of her
Shall have the chinks.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Is she a Capulet?
O dear account! my life is my foes debt.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Away begone, the sport is at the best.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I so I fear, the more is my unrest.

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: Nay gentlemen prepare not to be gone,
We have a trifling foolish banquet towards:
Is it even so? why then I thank you all.
I thank you honest gentlemen, good night:
More torches here, come on, then let us to bed.
Ah sirrah, by my faith it waxes late,
I will to my rest.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Come hither Nurse, what is yond gentleman?

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.l: The son and heir of old Tyberio.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: What is he that now is going out of door?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Marry that I think be young Petruchio.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What is he that follows here that wold not dance?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Go ask his name, if he be married,
My grave is like to be my wedding bed.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.l: His name is Romeo, and a Mountague,
The only son of your great enemy.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: My only love sprung from my only hate,
Too early seen, unknown, and known too late,
Prodigious birth of love it is to me,
That I must love a loathed enemy.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.l: What is it is? what is it is?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A rhyme I learnt even now
Of one I danced withal.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.l: Anon, anon:
Come let us away, the strangers all are gone.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Now old desire doth in his deathbed lie,
And young affection gapes to be his heir,
That fair for which love groaned for and would die,
With tender Iuliet match, is now not fair.
Now Romeo is beloved, and loves again,
Alike bewitched by the charm of looks:
But to his foe supposed he must complain,
And she steal love's sweet bait from fearful hooks:
Being held a foe, he may not have access
To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear,
And she as much in love, her means much less,
To meet her new beloved anywhere:
But passion lends them power, time means to meet,
Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Can I go forward when my heart is here,
Turn back dull earth and find thy Centre out.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Romeo, my Cousin Romeo, Romeo.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He is wise, and on my life hath stolen him home to bed.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: He ran this way and leapt this Orchard wall.
Call good Mercutio:
Nay I will conjure too.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Romeo, humours, madman, passion lover,
Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh,
Speak but one rhyme and I am satisfied:
Cry but aye me, provant, but love and day,
Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word,
One nickname for her purblind son and her,
Young Abraham: Cupid he that shot so true,
When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid.
He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not,
The Ape is dead, and I must conjure him.
I conjure thee by Rosalines bright eyes,
By her high forehead, and her Scarlet lip,
By her fine foot, straight leg, and quivering thigh,
And the demeans, that there adjacent lie,
That in thy likeness thou appear to us.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: And if he hear thee thou wilt anger him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: This cannot anger him, it would anger him
To raise a spirit in his mistress circle,
Of some strange nature, letting it there stand
Till she had laid it, and conjured it down,
That were some spite.
My invocation is fair and honest, in his mistress name,
I conjure only but to raise up him.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come, he hath hid himself among these trees
To be consorted with the humorous night:
Blind is his love, and best befits the dark.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark,
Now will he sit under a Meddler tree,
And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit,
As maids call Meddlers, when they laugh alone.
O Romeo that she were, o that she were
An open, or thou a Poprin Pear.
Romeo goodnight, I will to my truckle bed,
This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep,
Come shall we go?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Go then, for it is in vain to seek him here
That means not to be found.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: He jests at scars that never felt a wound,
But soft, what light through yonder window breaks?
It is the East, and Iuliet is the Sun.
Arise fair Sun and kill the envious Moon,
Who is already sick and pale with grief,
That thou her maid art far more fair than she:
Be not her maid since she is envious,
Her vestal livery is but sick and green,
And none but fools do wear it, cast it off:
It is my Lady, O it is my love, O that she knew she were,
She speaks, yet she says nothing, what of that?
Her eye discourses, I will answer it:
I am too bold, it is not to me she speaks:
Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven,
Having some business to entreat her eyes,
To twinkle in their spheres till they return.
What if her eyes were there, they in her head,
The brightness of her cheek wold shame those stars,
As daylight doth a lamp, her eye in heaven,
Would through the airy region stream so bright,
That birds would sing, and think it were not night:
See how she leans her cheek upon her hand.
O that I were a glove upon that hand,
That I might touch that cheek.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Aye me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: She speaks.
O speak again bright Angel, for thou art
As glorious to this night being over my head,
As is a winged messenger of heaven
Unto the white upturned wondering eyes,
Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him,
When he bestrides the lazy puffing Clouds,
And sails upon the bosom of the air.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: O Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo?
Deny thy father and refuse thy name:
Or if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love,
And I will no longer be a Capulet.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Shall I hear more, or shall I speak at this?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: It is but thy name that is my enemy:
Thou art thyself, though not a Mountague,
What is Mountague? it is nor hand nor foot,
Nor arm nor face, O be some other name
Belonging to a man.
What is in a name that which we call a rose,
By any other word would smell as sweet,
So Romeo would were he not Romeo called,
Retain that dear perfection which he owes,
Without that title, Romeo doff thy name,
And for thy name which is no part of thee,
Take all myself.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I take thee at thy word:
Call me but love, and I will be new baptised,
Henceforth I never will be Romeo.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: What man art thou, that thus bescreened in night
So stumblest on my counsel?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: By a name, I know not how to tell thee who I am:
My name dear saint, is hateful to myself,
Because it is an enemy to thee,
Had I it written, I would tear the word.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: My ears have yet not drunk a hundred words
Of thy tongues uttering, yet I know the sound.
Art thou not Romeo, and a Mountague?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Neither fair maid, if either thee dislike.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: How camest thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?
The Orchard walls are high and hard to climb,
And the place death, considering who thou art,
If any of my kinsmen find thee here.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: With love's light wings did I overperch these walls,
For stony limits cannot hold love out,
And what love can do, that dares love attempt:
Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: If they do see thee, they will murther thee.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Alack there lies more peril in thine eye,
Than twenty of their swords, look thou but sweet,
And I am proof against their enmity.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: I would not for the world they saw thee here.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I have nights cloak to hide me from their eyes,
If but thou love me, let them find me here,
My life were better ended by their hate,
Than death prorogued wanting of thy love.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: By whose direction foundest thou out this place?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: By love that first did prompt me to enquire,
He lent me counsel, and I lent him eyes:
I am no Pilot, yet wert thou as far
As that vast shore washeth with the farthest sea,
I should adventure for such merchandise.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Thou knowest the mask of night is on my face,
Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek,
For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight,
Fain would I dwell on form, fain, fain, deny
What I have spoke, but farewell complement.
Doest thou love me? I know thou wilt say Aye:
And I will take thy word, yet if thou swearest,
Thou mayst prove false at lovers' perjuries.
They say Jove laughs, o gentle Romeo,
If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully:
Or if thou thinkest I am too quickly won,
I will frown and be perverse, and say thee nay,
So thou wilt woo, but else not for the world,
In truth fair Montague I am too fond:
And therefore thou mayst think my behaviour light,
But trust me gentleman, I will prove more true,
Than those that have coying to be strange,
I should have been more strange, I must confess,
But that thou over-heardest ere I was ware,
My true-love passion, therefore pardon me,
And not impute this yielding to light love,
Which the dark night hath so discovered.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Lady, by yonder blessed Moon I vow,
That tips with silver all these fruit tree tops.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: O swear not by the moon the inconstant moon,
That monthly changes in her circle orb,
Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What shall I swear by?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Do not swear at all:
Or if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self,
Which is the god of my Idolatry,
And I will believe thee.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: If my hearts dear love.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Well do not swear, although I joy in thee:
I have no joy of this contract tonight,
It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden,
Too like the lightning which doth cease to be,
Ere one can say, it lightens, sweet goodnight:
This bud of love by Summer's ripening breath,
May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet,
Goodnight, goodnight, as sweet repose and rest,
Come to thy heart, as that within my breast.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: O wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: What satisfaction canst thou have tonight?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it:
And yet I would it were to give again.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Wouldst thou withdraw it, for what purpose love?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: But to be frank and give it thee again,
And yet I wish but for the thing I have,
My bounty is as boundless as the sea,
My love as deep, the more I give to thee
The more I have, for both are infinite:
I hear some noise within, dear love adieu:
Anon good nurse, sweet Mountague be true:
Stay but a little, I will come again.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: O blessed blessed night, I am afeared
Being in night, all this is but a dream,
Too flattering sweet to be substantial.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Three words dear Romeo, and goodnight indeed,
If that thy bent of love be honourable,
Thy purpose marriage, send me word tomorrow,
By one that I will procure to come to thee,
Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite,
And all my fortunes at thy foot I will lay,
And follow thee my Lord throughout the world.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I come, anon: but if thou meanest not well,
I do beseech thee

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: By and by I come:
To cease thy strife, and leave me to my grief,
Tomorrow will I send.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: So thrive my soul.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A thousand times goodnight.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: A thousand times the worse to want thy light,
Love goes toward love as schoolboy's from their books,
But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Hist Romeo hist, O for a falconers voice,
To lure this Tassel gentle back again,
Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud,
Else would I tear the Cave where Echo lies,
And make her airy tongue more hoarse, than
With repetition of my Romeo.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: It is my soul that calls upon my name.
How silver sweet, sound lovers' tongues by night,
Like softest music to attending ears.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Romeo.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: My Niece.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What o'clock tomorrow
Shall I send to thee?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: By the hour of nine.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I will not fail, it is twenty year till then,
I have forgot why I did call thee back.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Let me stand here till thou remember it.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I shall forget to have thee still stand there,
Remembering how I love thy company.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: And I will still stay, to have thee still forget,
Forgetting any other home but this.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: It is almost morning, I would have thee gone,
And yet no farther than a wantons bird,
That lets it hop a little from his hand,
Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gives,
And with a silken thread, plucks it back again,
So loving Jealous of his liberty.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I would I were thy bird.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Sweet so would I,
Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing:
Good night, good night.
Parting is such sweet sorrow,
That I shall say good night, till it be morrow.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Would I were sleep and peace so sweet to rest
The grey eyed morn smiles on the frowning night,
Checkering the Eastern Clouds with streaks of light,
And darkness fleckled like a drunkard reels,
From forth days pathway, made by Titans wheels.
Hence will I to my ghostly Friar's close cell,
His help to crave, and my dear hap to tell.

div2.stage: Enter Frier alone with a basket.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: The grey-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night,
Checking the Eastern clouds with streaks of light:
And fleckled darkness like a drunkard reels,
From forth days path, and Titans burning wheels:
Now ere the sun advance his burning eye,
The day to cheer, and nights dank dew to dry,
I must upfill this osier cage of ours,
With baleful weeds, and precious juiced flowers,
The earth that is natures mother is her tomb,
What is her burying grave, that is her womb:
And from her womb children of divers kind,
We sucking on her natural bosom find:
Many for many, vertues excellent:
None but for some, and yet all different.
O mickle is the powerful grace that lies
In Plants, herbs, stones, and their true qualities:
For naught so vile, that on the earth doth live,
But to the earth some special good doth give:
Nor aught so good but strained from that fair use,
Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse.
Virtue itself turns vice being misapplied,
And vice sometime by action dignified.
Within the infant rind of this weak flower
Poison hath residence, and medicine power:
For this being smelt with that part, cheers each part,
Being tasted, stays all senses with the heart.
Two such opposed Kings encamp them still,
In man as well as herbs, grace and rude will:
And where the worser is predominant,
Full soon the Canker death eats up that Plant.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Good morrow father.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Benedicte.
What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?
Young son, it argues a distempered head,
So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed:
Care keeps his watch in every old man's eye,
And where care lodges, sleep will never lie:
But where unbruised youth with unstuffed brain
Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign.
Therefore thy earliness doth me assure,
Thou art uproused with some distemperature:
Or if not so, then here I hit it right,
Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: That last is true, the sweeter rest was mine.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: God pardon sin, wast thou with Rosaline?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: With Rosaline, my ghostly father no,
I have forgot that name, and that names woe.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: That is my good son, but where hast thou been then?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I will tell thee ere thou ask it me again:
I have been feasting with mine enemy,
Where on a sudden one hath wounded me:
That is by me wounded both, our remedies
Within thy help and holy physic lies:
I bear no hatred blessed man: for lo
My intercession likewise steads my foe.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Be plain good son and homely in thy drift,
Riddling confession, finds but riddling shrift.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Then plainly know my heart's dear love is set
On the fair daughter of rich Capulet:
As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine,
And all combined, save what thou must combine
By holy marriage, when and where, and how,
We met, we wooed, and made exchange of vow:
I will tell thee as we pass, but this I pray,
That thou consent to marry us today.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Holy Saint Francis what a change is here?
Is Rosaline that thou didst love so dear,
So soon forsaken? young men's love then lies
Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.
Jesu Maria, what a deal of brine
Hath washed thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline?
How much salt water thrown away in waste,
To season love, that of it doth not taste.
The Sun not yet thy sighs, from heaven clears
Thy old groans yet ringing in mine ancient ears:
Lo here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit,
Of an old tear that is not washed off yet.
If ever thou wast thyself, and these woes thine,
Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline.
And art thou changed, pronounce this sentence then,
Women may fall, when there is no strength in men.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Thou chidest me oft for loving Rosaline.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: For doting, not for loving pupil mine.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: And badest me bury love.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Not in a grave,
To lay one in another out to have.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I pray thee chide me not, her I love now.
Doth grace for grace, and love for love allow:
The other did not so.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: O she knew well,
Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell:
But come young waverer, come go with me,
In one respect I will thy assistant be:
For this alliance may so happy prove,
To turn your households rancour to pure love.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: O let us hence, I stand on sudden haste.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Wisely and slow, they stumble that run fast.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Where the devil should this Romeo be? came he not
home tonight?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Not to his fathers, I spoke with his man.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why that same pale hard hearted wench, that Rosaline,
Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tibalt, the kinsman to old Capulet, hath sent a letter to his
fathers house.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A challenge on my life.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Romeo will answer it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Any man that can write may answer a letter.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Nay, he will answer the letters master how he dares, being
dared.

sp.speaker: Mercu.
sp.p:
Alas poor Romeo, he is already dead, stabbed with a
white wenches black eye, run through the ear with a love
song, the very pin of his heart, cleft with the blind
bow-boy's butt-shaft, and is he a man to encounter Tybalt?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Why what is Tybalt?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
More than Prince of Cats. O he is the courageous
captain of Complements: he fights as you sing pricksong, keeps
time, distance and proportion, he rests, his minim rests, one two,
and the third in your bosom: the very butcher of a silk button,
a duellist a duellist, a gentleman of the very first house of the
first and second cause, ah the immortal Passado, the Punto reuerso,
the Hay.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: The what?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
The Pox of such antique lisping affecting fantasies,
these new tuners of accent: by Jesu a very good blade, a very
tall man, a very good whore. Why is not this a lamentable thing
grandsire, that we should be thus afflicted with these strange
flies: these fashion-mongers, these pardons mes, who stand so
much on the new form, that they cannot sit at ease on the old
bench. O their bones, their bones.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Here Comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Without his Roe, like a dried Herring, O flesh, flesh,
how art thou fishified? now is he for the numbers that Petrach
flowed in: Laura to his Lady, was a kitchen wench, marry
she had a better love to berhyme her: Dido a dowdy, Cleopatra
a Gypsy, Helen and Hero, hildings and harlots: Thisbie a grey
eye or so, but not to the purpose. Seignior Romeo, Bonieur, there is
a French salutation to your French slop: you gave us the counterfeit
fairly last night.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
Good morrow to you both, what counterfeit did I give
you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: The slip sir, the slip, can you not conceive?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
Pardon good Mercutio,my business was great, and in
such a case as mine, a man may strain courtesy.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
That is as much as to say, such a case as yours, constrains
a man to bow in the hams.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Meaning to curtsy.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Thou hast most kindly hit it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: A most courteous exposition.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nay I am the very pink of courtesy.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Pink for flower.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Why then is my pump well flowered.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Sure wit follow me this jest, now till thou hast worn
out thy pump, that when the single sole of it is worn, the jest
may remain after the wearing, solely singular.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: O single solid jest, solely singular for the singleness.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come between us good Benuolio, my wits faints.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Switches and spurs, switches and spurs, or I will cry a match.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Nay, if our wits run the wildgoose chase, I am done:
For thou hast more of the wildgoose in one of thy wits, than I
am sure I have in my whole five. Was I with you there for the
goose?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
Thou wast never with me for anything, when thou wast
not there for the goose.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Nay good goose bite not.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Thy wit is very bitter sweeting, it is a most sharp sauce.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: And is it not then well served in to a sweet goose?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
O here is a wit of Cheverel, that stretches from an
inch narrow, to an ell broad.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
I stretch it out for that word broad, which added to the
goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Why is not this better now than groaning for love,now
art thou sociable, now art thou Romeo: now art thou what thou
art, by art as well as by nature, for this drivelling love is like a
great natural that runs lolling up and down to hide his babble
in a hole.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Stop there, stop there.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Thou desirest me to stop in my tale against the hare.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
O thou art deceived; I would have made it short, for I
was come to the whole depth of my tale, and meant indeed to
occupy the argument no longer.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here is goodly gear.
A sail, a sail.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Two two, a shirt and a smock.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Peter:

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Anon.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: My fan Peter.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good Peter to hide her face, for her fan is the fairer face.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: God ye good morrow Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: God ye goodden fair gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Is it good den?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
It is no less I tell ye, for the bawdy hand of the dial,
is now upon the prick of noon.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Out upon you, what a man are you?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: One gentlewoman, that God hath made, himself to mar.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
By my troth it is well said, for himself to mar quoth he?
Gentlemen can any of you tell me where I may find the young Romeo?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you
have found him, than he was when you sought him: I am the
youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: You say well.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yea is the worst well, very well took, i'faith, wisely, wisely.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: If you be he sir, I desire some confidence with you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: She will indict him to some supper.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A bawd, a bawd, a bawd. So ho.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: What hast thou found?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
No hare sir, unless a hare sir in a lenten pie, that is something
stale and hoar ere it be spent.
An old hare hoar, and an old hare hoar is very good meat in
lent.
But a hare that is hoar, is too much for a score, when it hoars ere
it be spent.
Romeo, will you come to your fathers? we will to dinner thither.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Farewell ancient Lady, farewell Lady, Lady, Lady.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
I pray you sir, what saucy merchant was this that was
so full of his ropery?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
A gentleman Nurse, that loves to hear himself talk,
and will speak more in a minute, than he will stand too in a
month.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
If he speak anything against me, I will take him down,
if he were lustier than he is, and twenty such Iacks: and if I
cannot, I will find those that shall: scurvy knave, I am none
of his flurt gills, I am none of his skeins mates, and thou must
stand by too and suffer every knave to use me at his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I saw no man use you at his pleasure: if I had, my weapon
should quickly have been out: I warrant you, I dare draw as soon
as another man, if I see occasion in a good quarrel, and the law on
my side.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
Now afore God, I am so vexed, that every part about me
quivers, scurvy knave: pray you sir a word: and as I told you,
my young Lady bid me enquire you out, what she bid me say, I
will keep to myself: but first let me tell ye, if ye should lead
her in a fools paradise, as they say, it were a very gross kind of
behaviour as they say: for the Gentlewoman is young: and therefore,
if you should deal double with her, truly it were an ill
thing to be offered to any Gentlewoman, and very weak dealing

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p:
Nurse, commend me to thy Lady and Mistress, I protest
unto thee.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
Good heart, and i'faith I will tell her as much: Lord, Lord,
she will be a joyful woman.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
What wilt thou tell her Nurse? thou dost not mark
me?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
I will tell her sir, that you do protest, which as I take it,
is a gentlemanlike offer.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Bid her devise some means to come to shrift this afternoon,
And there she shall at Friar Lawrence Cell
Be shrived and married: here is for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: No truly sir not a penny.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Go to, I say you shall.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: This afternoon sir, well she shall be there.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: And stay good Nurse behind the Abbey wall,
Within this hour my man shall be with thee,
And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair,
Which to the high top gallant of my joy,
Must be my convoy in the secret night.
Farewell be trusty, and I will quit thy pains:
Farewell, commend me to thy Mistress.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Now God in heaven bless thee, hark you sir.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What sayst thou my dear Nurse?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Is your man secret, did you never here say, two may keep
counsel putting one away.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Warrant thee my man is as true as steel.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Well sir, my Mistress is the sweetest Lady, Lord, Lord,
when it was a little prating thing. O there is a Noble man in town
one Paris, that would fain lay knife aboard: but she good soul
had as lief see a toad, a very toad as see him: I anger her sometimes,
and tell her that Paris is the properer man, but I will warrant
you, when I say so, she looks as pale as any clout in the versal
world, doth not Rosemary and Romeo begin both with a letter?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I Nurse, what of that? Both with an R.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
A mocker that is the dog, name R. is for the no, I know
it begins with some other letter, and she hath the prettiest sententious
of it, of you and Rosemary, that it would do you good
to hear it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Commend me to thy Lady.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Aye a thousand times Peter.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Anon.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Before and apace.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The clock struck nine when I did send the Nurse,
In half an hour she promised to return,
Perchance she cannot meet him, that is not so:
O she is lame, love's heralds should be thoughts,
Which ten times faster glides than the Suns beams,
Driving back shadows over lowering hills.
Therefore do nimble pinioned doves draw love,
And therefore hath the wind swift Cupid wings:
Now is the Sun upon the highmost hill,
Of this days journey, and from nine till twelve,
Is there long hours, yet she is not come,
Had she affections and warm youthful blood,
She would be as swift in motion as a ball,
My words would bandy her to my sweet love.
And his to me, but old folks, many fain as they were dead,
Unwieldy, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.
O God she comes, o honey Nurse what news?
Hast thou met with him? send thy man away.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Peter stay at the gate.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Now good sweet Nurse, O Lord, why lookest thou sad?
Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily.
If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news,
By playing it to me, with so sour a face.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: I am a weary, give me leave a while,
Fie how my bones ache, what a jaunce have I?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I would thou hadst my bones, and I thy news:
Nay come I pray thee speak, good good Nurse speak.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Jesu what haste, can you not stay a while?
Do you not see that I am out of breath?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: How art thou out of breath, when thou hast breath
To say to me, that thou art out of breath?
The excuse that thou doest make in this delay,
Is longer than the tale thou doest excuse.
Is thy news good or bad? answer to that,
Say either, and I will stay the circumstance:
Let me be satisfied, is it good or bad?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
Well, you have made a simple choice, you know not
how to choose a man: Romeo, no not he though his face be better
than any man's, yet his leg excels all men's, and for a hand
and a foot and a body, though they be not to be talked on, yet
they are past compare: he is not the flower of courtesy, but I will
warrant him, as gentle as a lamb: go thy ways wench, serve
God. What have you dined at home?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: No, no. But all this did I know before.
What says he of our marriage, what of that?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Lord how my head aches, what a head have I?
It beats as it would fall in twenty pieces.
My back a the other side, a my back, my back:
Beshrew your heart for sending me about
To catch my death with jauncing up and down.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I'faith I am sorry that thou art not well.
Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me what says my love?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
Your love says like an honest gentleman,
And a Courteous, and a kind, and a handsome,
And I warrant a virtuous, where is your mother?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Where is my mother, why she is within, where should she be?
How oddly thou repliest:
Your love says like an honest gentleman,
Where is your mother?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O Gods lady dear,
Are you so hot, marry come up I trow,
Is this the poultice for my aching bones:
Henceforward do your messages yourself.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Here is such a coil, come what says Romeo?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Have you got leave to go to shrift today?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Then high you hence to Friar Lawrence Cell,
There stays a husband to make you a wife:
Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks,
They will be in scarlet straight at any news:
Hie you to Church, I must another way,
To fetch a Ladder by the which your love
Must climb a birds nest soon when it is dark,
I am the drudge, and toil in your delight:
But you shall bear the burthen soon at night.
Go I will to dinner, hie you to the Cell.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Hie to high fortune, honest Nurse farewell.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: So smile the heavens upon this holy act,
That after hours, with sorrow chide us not.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Amen, amen, but come what sorrow can,
It cannot countervail the exchange of joy
That one short minute gives me in her sight:
Do thou but close our hands with holy words,
Then love-devouring death do what he dare,
It is enough I may but call her mine.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: These violent delights have violent ends,
And in their triumph die like fire and powder:
Which as they kiss consume. The sweetest honey
Is loathsome in his own deliciousness,
And in the taste confounds the appetite.
Therefore love moderately, long love doth so,
Too swift arrives, as tardy as too slow.
Here comes the Lady, O so light a foot
Will never wear out the everlasting flint,
A lover may bestride the gossamers,
That idles in the wanton summer air,
And yet not fall, so light is vanity.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Good evening to my ghostly confessor.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Romeo shall thank thee daughter for us both.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Ah Iuliet, if the measure of thy joy
Be heaped like mine, and that thy skill be more
To blazon it, then sweeten with thy breath
This neighbour air and let rich music tongue,
Unfold the imagined happiness that both
Receive in either, by this dear encounter.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Conceit more rich in matter than in words,
Brags of his substance, not of ornament,
They are but beggars that can count their worth,
But my true love is grown to such excess,
I cannot sum up sum of half my wealth.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Come, come with me, and we will make short work.
For by your leaves, you shall not stay alone,
Till holy Church incorporate two in one.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I pray thee good Mercutio let us retire,
The day is hot, the Capels abroad:
And if we meet we shall not scape a brawl, for now these hot
days, is the mad blood stirring.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Thou art like one of these fellows, that when he enters
the confines of a Tavern, claps me his sword upon the table,
and says, God send me no need of thee: and by the operation
of the second cup, draws him on the drawer, when indeed there
is no need.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Am I like such a fellow?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Come, come, thou art as hot a Iacke in thy mood as
any in Italy: and as soon moved to be moody, and as soon
moody to be moved.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: And what too?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Nay if there were two such, we should have none
shortly, for one would kill the other: thou, why thou wilt
quarrel with a man that hath a hair more, or a hair less in his
beard, than thou hast: thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking
Nuts, having no other reason, but because thou hast hazel eyes:
what eye, but such an eye wold spy out such a quarrel? thy head
is as full of quarrels, as an egg is full of meat, and yet thy
head hath been beaten as addle as an egg for quarrelling: thou
hast quarrelled with a man for coughing in the street, because he
hath wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun. Didst
thou not fall out with a taylor for wearing his new doublet before
Easter, with another for tying his new shoes with old riband,
and yet thou wilt tutor me from quarrelling?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
If I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man should
buy the fee-simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: The fee-simple, o simple.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: By my head here comes the Capulets.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: By my heel I care not.

sp.speaker: Tybalt.
sp.l: Follow me close, for I will speak to them.
Gentlemen, Good den, a word with one of you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
And but one word with one of us, couple it with something,
make it a word and a blow.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p:
You shall find me apt enough to that sir, if you will give
me occasion.

sp.speaker: Mercu.
sp.p: Could you not take some occasion without giving?

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: Mercutio, thou consortest with Romeo.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Consort, what doest thou make us Minstrels? and thou
make Minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but discords: here is
my fiddlestick, here is that shall make you dance: s'wounds consort.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: We talk here in the public haunt of men:
Either withdraw unto some private place,
Or reason coldly of your grievances:
Or else depart, here all eyes gaze on us.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Men's eyes were made to look, and let them gaze.
I will not budge for no man's pleasure I.

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: Well peace be with you sir, here comes my man.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But I will be hanged sir if he wear your livery:
Marry go before to field, he will be your follower,
Your worship in that sense may call him man.

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: Romeo, the love I bear thee, can afford
No better term than this: thou art a villain.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee,
Doth much excuse the appertaining rage
To such a greeting: villain am I none.
Therefore farewell, I see thou knowest me not.

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries
That thou hast done me, therefore turn and draw.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I do protest I never injured thee,
But love thee better than thou canst devise:
Till thou shalt know the reason of my love,
And so good Capulet, which name I tender
As dearly as mine own, be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O calm, dishonourable, vile submission:
Alla staccato carries it away,
Tibalt, you rat-catcher, will you walk?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: What wouldst thou have with me?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Good King of Cats, nothing but one of your nine lives,
that I mean to make bold withal, and as you shall use me
hereafter dry beat the rest of the eight. Will you pluck your
sword out of his pilcher by the ears? Make haste, lest mine be
about your ears ere it be out.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am for you.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Gentle Mercutio, put thy Rapier up.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come sir, your Passado.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Draw Benuolio, beat down their weapons,
Gentlemen, for shame forbear this outrage,
Tibalt, Mercutio, the Prince expressly hath
Forbid this bandying in Verona streets,
Hold Tybalt, good Mercutio.

sp.p: Away Tybalt.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am hurt.
A plague on both houses, I am sped,
Is he gone and hath nothing.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: What art thou hurt?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, a scratch, a scratch, marry it is enough,
Where is my Page? go villain, fetch a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Courage man, the hurt cannot be much.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
No it is not so deep as a well, nor so wide as a Church
door, but it is enough, it will serve: ask for me tomorrow, and you
shall find me a grave man. I am peppered I warrant, for this
world, a plague on both your houses, sounds a dog, a rat, a mouse,
a cat, to scratch a man to death: a braggart, a rogue, a villain,
that fights by the book of arithmetic, why the devil came you
between us? I was hurt under your arm.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I thought all for the best.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Help me into some house Benuolio,
Or I shall faint, a plague on both your houses.
They have made worms meat of me,
I have it, and soundly, to your houses.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: This Gentleman the Princes near ally,
My very friend hath got this mortal hurt
In my behalf, my reputation stained
With Tybalts slander, Tybalt that an hour
Hath been my Cozen, O sweet Iuliet,
Thy beauty hath made me effeminate,
And in my temper softened valours steel.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: O Romeo,Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead,
That gallant spirit hath aspired the Clouds,
Which too untimely here did scorn the earth.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: This days black fate, on mo days doth depend,
This but begins, the woe others must end.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: He gan in triumph and Mercutio slain,
Away to heaven, respective lenity,
And fire end fury, be my conduct now,
Now Tybalt take the villain back again,
That late thou gavest me, for Mercutios soul
Is but a little way above our heads,
Staying for thine to keep him company:
Either thou or I, or both, must go with him.

sp.speaker: Ty.
sp.l: Thou wretched boy that didst consort him here,
Shalt with him hence.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: This shall determine that.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Romeo, away be gone:
The Citizens are up, and Tybalt slain,
Stand not amazed, the Prince will doom thee death,
If thou art taken, hence be gone away.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: O I am fortunes fool.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Why dost thou stay?

sp.speaker: Citti.
sp.l: Which way ran he that killed Mercutio?
Tybalt that murderer, which way ran he?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: There lies that Tybalt.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: Up sir, go with me:
I charge thee in the Princes name obey.

div2.stage: Enter Prince, olde Mountague, Capulet, their wives and all.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Where are the vile beginners of this fray?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: O Noble Prince, I can discover all:
The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl,
There lies the man slain by young Romeo,
That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.

sp.speaker: Capu.Wi.
sp.l: Tybalt, my Cousin, O my brothers child,
O Prince, O Cozen, husband, O the blood is spilled
Of my dear kinsman, Prince as thou art true,
For blood of ours, shed blood of Mountague.
O Cousin, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Benuolio, who began this bloody fray?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tybalt here slain, whom Romeos hand did slay,
Romeo that spoke him fair, bid him bethink
How nice the quarrel was, and urged withal
Your high displeasure all this uttered,
With gentle breath, calm look, knees humbly bowed
Could not take truce with the unruly spleen
Of Tybalt deaf to peace, but that he tilts
With piercing steel at bold Mercutios breast,
Who all as hot, turns deadly point to point,
And with a Martial scorn, with one hand beats
Cold death aside, and with the other sends
It back to Tybalt, whose dexterity
Retorts it, Romeo he cries aloud,
Hold friends, friends part, and swifter than his tongue,
His aged arm beats down their fatal points,
And twixt them rushes, underneath whose arm,
An envious thrust from Tybalt, hit the life
Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled,
But by and by comes back to Romeo,
Who had but newly entertained revenge,
And to it they go like lightning, for ere I
Could draw to part them, was stout Tybalt slain:
And as he fell, did Romeo turn and fly,
This is the truth, or let Benuolio die.

sp.speaker: Ca.Wi.
sp.l: He is a kinsman to the Mountague,
Affection makes him false, he speaks not true:
Some twenty of them fought in this black strife,
And all those twenty could but kill one life.
I beg for Justice which thou Prince must give:
Romeo slew Tybalt, Romeo must not live.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Romeo slew him, he slew Mercutio,
Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe.

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: Not Romeo Prince, he was Mercutios friend,
His fault concludes, but what the law should end,
The life of Tybalt.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: And for that offence,
Immediately we do exile him hence:
I have an interest in your hearts proceeding:
My blood for your rude brawls doth lie a-bleeding.
But I will amerce you with so strong a fine,
That you shall all repent the loss of mine.
It will be deaf to pleading and excuses,
Nor tears, nor prayers shall purchase out abuses.
Therefore use none, let Romeo hence in haste,
